pages.image_alt: Game being translated into different languages
pages.title: What is Game Localization? 🤔
pages.text: Game localization is the process of adapting a video game to a specific locale or market. It involves translation of text, adaptation of cultural references, conversion of units and currencies, and more, to make the game more accessible and enjoyable for players from different regions.

pages.image: A bar graph showing the increase in game sales after localization
pages.image_alt: Graph showing increase in game sales after localization
pages.title: The Impact of Localization 📈
pages.text: Game localization can significantly boost your game's sales. By making your game accessible to a wider audience, you can tap into new markets, increase your player base, and improve your revenue. According to a report by Newzoo, localized games see a 128% increase in downloads and a 26% increase in revenue on average.
pages.footer: Source: Newzoo Global Games Market Report

pages.image: A map pinpointing countries with high game revenues that are non-English speaking
pages.image_alt: Map showing high-revenue game markets that are non-English speaking
pages.title: Potential Markets for Localization 🌏
pages.text: There are numerous non-English speaking markets with high game revenues, including China, Japan, South Korea, Germany, and Russia. By localizing your game for these markets, you can significantly boost your game's global reach and profitability.
pages.footer: Source: Newzoo Global Games Market Report

pages.image: A checklist for game localization process
pages.title: Getting Started with Localization 📝
pages.text: Getting started with game localization involves several steps: 1) Research your target markets, 2) Translate and localize your game content, 3) Test your localized game, 4) Market your game in the target markets. Remember, localization is more than just translation - it's about adapting your game to fit the cultural context of your target market.
pages.footer: Source: IGDA Best Practices for Game Localization

🌍🎮 Game Localization: Your Gateway to Global Success 🚀
A globe with different game icons representing various countries, in a minimalist art style
Globe with game icons representing various countries

What is Game Localization? 🤔
Game localization is the process of adapting a video game to a specific locale or market. It involves translation of text, adaptation of cultural references, conversion of units and currencies, and more, to make the game more accessible and enjoyable for players from different regions.
An illustration of a game being translated into different languages, with speech bubbles in various languages coming out from a game console
Game being translated into different languages
Source: International Game Developers Association (IGDA)

The Impact of Localization 📈
Game localization can significantly boost your game's sales. By making your game accessible to a wider audience, you can tap into new markets, increase your player base, and improve your revenue. According to a report by Newzoo, localized games see a 128% increase in downloads and a 26% increase in revenue on average.
A bar graph showing the increase in game sales after localization
Graph showing increase in game sales after localization
Source: Newzoo Global Games Market Report

Potential Markets for Localization 🌏
There are numerous non-English speaking markets with high game revenues, including China, Japan, South Korea, Germany, and Russia. By localizing your game for these markets, you can significantly boost your game's global reach and profitability.
A map pinpointing countries with high game revenues that are non-English speaking
Map showing high-revenue game markets that are non-English speaking
Source: Newzoo Global Games Market Report

Getting Started with Localization 📝
Getting started with game localization involves several steps: 1) Research your target markets, 2) Translate and localize your game content, 3) Test your localized game, 4) Market your game in the target markets. Remember, localization is more than just translation - it's about adapting your game to fit the cultural context of your target market.

Source: IGDA Best Practices for Game Localization
